title: What will be the closing yield for the 10-year US Treasury on 16 September 2021?
preds: Time is up.  I'll move to 100%, even though there is virtually no difference in Brier score between 99% and 100%.  It's a square function, and 0.01^2 = 0.0001, i.e., almost zero.
downside risk negligible with just 4 days to go
Vanishingly slight chance of yield leaping above 1.5%

The 10-year US Treasury yield has remained between 1.000 and 1.500 since June. It is likely they will remain there for the next two weeks, barring any massive events or disasters. However, the 10-year yield is currently rising, and it is possible that it could surpass 1.500 by the 16th.
Crowd certainty seems crazy. 13 bp move could easily happen from current levels of 1.37%. Affirming current forecast.
I believe that everything is starting to bounce back up from covid and things are going to go back to where they were at before covid.

The inflation rate has stabilized and unemployment has begin to drop as business continues to return to normal. Along with this, there has been overemphasis on the danger of the Covid-19 delta variant.
It looked like it might decline during August, but it has since stabilized.
For some reason, the crowd is not considering the highly unlikely, but still meaningful risk of falling yields ~ 1-2%.

Based off of the current yield, the 10 year treasury rate has been hovering around the 1.500 mark, so I think a good prediction is that it will stay in that range for at least the next two weeks. Unless something major happens, I believe that the rate will fall somewhere between the 1.000 and the 1.500 mark.

The closing yield for the 10-year US Treasury has taken quite the hit since the Delta variant has became a little bit more rampant.  Ever since this occurred in July, the Treasury has remained between 1.000 and 1.500.  Because September 16 is just 13 days away, I really cannot forecast anything that would change this dramatically.  If it were out another month or so, I may put more emphasis on the category of less than 1.000 because some scientists are saying that the variant could become even worse in the winter months, similar to what happened last winter.
Pushing up slightly on jobs report, but not too much given the short time remaining. Reassessing on Tuesday.

I set a low probability in the less than 1.0000 range since it has not hit this level since March of this year. I put 92% on the 1.500 but less than 2.0000 range because it has seemed to be in this range recently and consistently. I put a small probability (7%) for the between 2.0000 and 2.50000 range because I thought there could be a chance that it passed 1.5000 based off of the previous graph trend.
Amortising towards the close of 16 Sept.
Based on trend patterns, there is a very likely the rate will stay between 1.000 and 1.50; however, there could be a crazy event, either putting it between 2.000 and 2.500 or less than 1.000.

I chose this value because the close date is so near and the fed in general is being pretty stagnate. Interest rates play a big part in the value of borrowing, so it wouldn't make sense for the rate to do anything drastic because it has such a wide effect.
No prediction should be at zero so made sure each one had a bit of a chance and I thought it would most likely be around the 1.5 range so I put as much around then as I could.
The yield has consistently been between 1.00 and 1.5 since June of 2021. The likelihood that it remains within that range in September is high.

1.22 - July,30 -
1.30 - Aug, 7
1.28 - Aug, 15
1.26 - Aug, 23
1.32 - Aug, 31
trend = Stable
Min- Aug, 2 - 1,17

A stock market correction is a real possibility with Delta impacting the economy and federal unemployment benefits expiring. This could push the yield below 1.0%. I believe it is unlikely the prospect of tapering by the Fed will push rates above 1.5% in the small window that remains.
update on reaction to Jackson Hole

Firm support around 1.2% limits the probability of <1.0%
Strong supply areas at 1.36% and 1.43%.
1.34%. Assuming 70 bps annual yield vol (20 bps vol til the expiry of this question).
It appears that rates are backing up quite quickly - https://cnb.cx/3mwnEGh. Close on a 5% change in the last 24 hours. @Juliabizz / @Wildwood2000

Comprehensive article listing & weighing what is on the Fed's plate. One factor not mentioned -- to what extent is wanting to keep his job come Feb 2022 staying Powell's hand?  https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-fed-jacksonhole-framework-analysi/analysis-inflation-vs-jobs-hole-a-tradeoff-the-fed-still-hopes-to-skirt-idUSKBN2FQ0RK

Jackson Hole likely to be a non-starter. As @Juliabizz says, https://bit.ly/3gusIam, Treasuries haven't lost safe haven status and USD holding up. Some disruption on Capitol Hill about which parts of which legislation and stimulus packages will be agreed, in spite of the slim majority the Dems hold and Delta still running wild in spite of Pfizer's formal approval by FDA. Unemployment is at a 17 month low (https://reut.rs/3DdurKX). However, 337k is a long way from 200k-250k and employment is apparently a major factor for the FED. The 'early' withdrawal of stimulus / support payments in some (Republican) states doesn't appear to have generated significant increases in employment that some expected; https://reut.rs/3jcWGRQ. Inflation may well be transitional as there appear to be fewer hawks amongst the regional FEDs now than 2-3 weeks ago.  So, finally following @Wildwood2000 (https://bit.ly/2WkrHe9)

Going with the crowd to up weight on 1.0-1.5 range.  Fed seems more minded to taper but still is talk, and not action. Also seeing what @bh4eh sees, Treasuries havent lost 'safe haven' status for Rest of World & USD holding up.

As of writing this the interest rate is 1.26
However, Fed has indicated that it will taper bond purchases and is already doing massive reverse repo open market activity (exceeding 1Tr $). With Fed not being on the buying side of the US treasury the prices will fall a bit lower and yield would go up. Fed doesn't seem to want a massive shock to the yields just yet, so it will probably be a few ~10-15 basis points at best bringing it pretty close to 1.5
Reiteration, having noted the strengthening dollar (DXY).
Current Yield: 1.25%, having rejected 1.4% last week and confirmed a failed double bottom. Bias is lower for now.

Foreign purchases keeping yields low? - https://reut.rs/3CW1PWg and some risk aversion too - https://reut.rs/3ARtOov. All that in spite of continuing talk of tapering announcements in the next month or so; https://reut.rs/3ARtOov @Juliabizz / @Wildwood2000

1.30 - Aug, 7
1.28 - Aug, 15
trend = Stable
Min- Aug, 2 - 1,17
Rejected the 1.4%, lost around 10% since. Horrible candle Friday 13th Aug. Bias is lower.

I am tempted to load up a bit more on bucket 2 albeit, the short squeeze is apparently over, there's pushback in the bond market and equity earnings are looking quite good, inflation is looking increasingly 'transitory' and the FED is likely to remain supportive for a few months longer although forward guidance on tapering is likely by Q4. In other words, a true market with sellers and buyers heading in opposite directions, which is looking fairly finely balanced at the moment....
Double bottom confirmed with the break of 1.3% so I've increased the 1.5-2.0% basket likelihood slightly. 1.4% remains my main pivot point. I'm expecting choppiness at that level.
Stronger USD, weaker commodities & gold, delta fears and higher jobs numbers....the end of the short squeeze? means a small adjustment IMO.

Seasonal factors will likely impact jobs data for July and also August to some extent (summer schools, auto retooling etc.) and while that along with potential supplies driven surprise in headline inflation numbers in the short run may push 10 year yield above 1.5% sporadically, the fed is likely to continue to talk down the tapering probability by pointing to transitory factors behind jobs and inflation.

A bit late to the game on this one but I'm satisfied about my current forecast as well as the crowd. Might have to chase that median going forward.
Today's upward move on a good employment report was a surprise to me.  [But then I'm not an economist.]  I'll move some chips from the "Less than 1.00" bucket to "More then 1.50 but less than 2.00."
Rejected move lower: Put in a double bottom, confirmed by breaking up through 1.28%. Supply likely around 1.4% in the coming weeks but I will pivot aggressively should it break through that level.

Needed to revise my forecast because the rate fell 0.4% over the past 3 months.

Shifting from a reflation to stagflation-ahead view.

Time adjustment.  1.4% remains my bull pivot
Close at 1.27% today, time is running out.
1.29% now and seems to have stabilized. I never would have guessed 10-year Treasury bond movements would become so interesting, but here we are. :)

Adjusting odds to acknowledge steep drop in yields. Treasury market reflecting views growth & inflation is peaking; Fed could be more proactive on tightening than previously thought & also search for USD safe haven. Can't shake off view that  yields are too low relative to the economic outlook in 2H21 and 2022 but countervailing market moves now unlikely before close of question on 16 Sept.
Downward trend and passage of time.
Revising a bit since it's now at 1.12%. Very surprised by this. At this point "Less than 1.000" is a lot closer than "More than 1.500," but the crowd odds are not reflecting that

A bit of a risky forecast but today's market action and fear of delta spreading (https://on.mktw.net/3xSL0Zs) and fear that economic growth has peaked (https://bloom.bg/3kF4pJT) a flash in the pan of the beginning of the deeper correction many have feared? If kit's the latter, 1% is a serious possibility? ....but still a way to go in 8 weeks..... @Juliabizz / @Wildwood2000 / @MCowley /

It just dipped below 1.25%! There’s an argument out there articulated by Cathie Woods among others that there are deflationary forces and dollar strength forces out there, which is being reflected in the bond market
It's barely at 1.3% right now. The crowd odds of 54% seem still a bit too low, with only 2 months remaining until close.
Wisdom is knowing the truth deeply enough to optimize the specifics.

A slight adjustment following Powell's testimony and not fighting the market (or the FED!) just yet. The FED's overnight repo numbers may add to the story; https://on.mktw.net/3krATXI. Flagging unemployment and Delta CoV-19 add to the picture; https://on.mktw.net/3epq1FV @Juliabizz / @SE_Meyer / @Wildwood2000
Adjusting for the present market close print of 1.415

Latest inflation far from well behaved. Wage growth, supply side bottlenecks active issues. But, third wave of infections putting some damper on global pace of reopening and a bit of capitulation to view that the Fed wont let inflation feed on itself too much. Hence the flattening curve.

Pretty dramatic drop in yields over the past few months. At least some part of this would be due to the unwind of the TGA, leading to insufficient collateral (treasuries) in the financial system. This will be continuing until the end of July, at which point I expect that downwards pressure to lessen. No idea how large of an effect this amounts to, or how rapidly it would take place -- if I did, I'd be in a different career. With the Fed hinting about tapering soon (though tapering is the wrong word, it would just be deceleration), I would expect/am surprised at the lack of increase in yields.
The no-change forecast is between 1.0 and 1.5. I expect that rates will resume their upward trend before the close of the question.

"ost analysts had forecast 10 year Treasury yields to hit around 2% by this point in the recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. However, that hasn't happened, which is leading some on Wall Street to try to discern what the Treasury bond moves, including a flattening in the yield curve, or difference between yields on short-dated notes and longer-dated bonds, means for the economic outlook.
"

1.288% now, close to the middle of the 2nd bin.  The recent drop seems to have caught many investors by surprise.  https://www.reuters.com/business/finance/falling-us-bond-yields-may-signal-death-knell-reflation-stock-trade-2021-07-08/ I'll put the odds at 2 to 1 that ten weeks from now the 10-yr rate won't exceed 1.5%.
I can't believe I'm giving probability to sub 1%, but at this point I'm forced to.

Plenty of room for things to change; https://reut.rs/3dPkJmU Late Q3 is likely to be more revealing; "It could be that the 1.77% U.S. 10-year nominal yield level touched in March will remain this year's high as more of the "reflation" bets are forced to unwind, according to Mike Sewell, a portfolio manager at T.Rowe Price." It's possible the shorts are being squeezed now and there's more acceptance that inflation could be 'transitory' and employment isn't coming back as fast as the market hoped / expected?
@Juliabizz / @SE_Meyer / @Wildwood2000
My bias skews heavily around the 1.4% pivot.
Maybe the MMT guys were right..Looks like the supply of easy money will never end!

Previous 16 weeks have carefully backtested the 1.4% area; it never reached 'oversold' and there is positive divergence forming on the daily.  As long as we are above 1.4% and the positive divergence remains valid, my bias is strongly bullish.
Every choice rules out a panoply of others.
Breakeven turns lower...for 5 & 10s....is the expected inflation transitory indeed? See - https://cnb.cx/3yc9i0x @Juliabizz  / @SE_Meyer
Backtested its breakout yield of 1.42% this week. Technically speaking, that is a potential springboard area.

Unemployment claims are still more than double the 'healthy' labour market rate; https://reut.rs/3A5oY7w and US10YT holding below 1.5%....just. The FED's continuing 'mixed messages' continue to cause some confusion; https://reut.rs/3zX1cKT. I'd suggest the FED is happy around 1.5% for the US10T for the time being and we may know more from the next FOMC on 27/28 July? We'll also have had some more employment numbers by then and know more about the possible effects of the 25 GOP states (i.e.50% of the states in effect) that will end income support earlier than the federal government plans (thanks to @Juliabizz - https://bit.ly/3jaLjKE).
@SE_Meyer

Agree @bh4eh. The juggle between the twin goals is the nub. Right now, employment isnt coming back as fast as inflation.  The outcome from this might shed some light. Albeit unintentionally, it sets up a ‘controlled experiment’ between the Democrat vs Republican run states. 
https://www.npr.org/2021/06/07/1003002951/a-lifeline-for-the-unemployed-is-about-to-end-in-half-of-u-s-heres-whats-at-stak?t=1624353910074 Returning to question at hand, before Sept 16, there is zero chance the Fed will actually act to raise rates or reverse QE. But how ‘Fedspeak’ evolves and how markets perceive the Fed’s credibility is another matter. Here’s a good illustration:  https://www.reuters.com/article/usa-bonds-idUSL2N2O01WR
TREASURIES-U.S. Treasury yield curve flattens as Fed seen more proactive on inflation | Reuters It went one way last week. It could go the other way next time.  In the round, am further raising the odds to 95% on the 1.5-2% band. But still think that >2% is a more reasonable possibility than < 1.5% (0%) as inflationary pressures surprise on the upside.

Over 1.5 since Mar 
top on Mar, 31 and falling despite inflationary pressure.
FED hawkish posture shoul keep low.

Powell to indicate his focus on employment, support for the economy and Covid-19 concerns; https://tmsnrt.rs/3wORAjb Also noteworthy comments; https://on.mktw.net/2TNm2M2  & https://on.mktw.net/35Gs3g7 @Juliabizz / @SE_Meyer / @Wildwood2000
Flatter yield curve, higher FF range, increase in inflation expectations will keep 10yr TNote yields in a narrow band.

Festering inflation in April, May, June; an accelerating US economic recovery, a slightly hawkish turn by the Fed (this week’s FOMC kept the federal-funds rate at 0.0%-0.25% — unsurprising -- but updated the dot plot to pen in the first rate hikes in 2023 rather than 2024).  Yet Treasury yields fell in response. Hmm. Did not expect that. That said, in 2Q the ferociously infectious Delta variant & still-tight vaccine supply tamped economic activity in the ROW. Plus seems to be some dialling back of the fiscal trillions as the US Congress negotiates. Moving my forecast (previously 50%) closer to the crowd in putting the greatest weight on on the 10yr yield staying btw 1.5-2% in 3Q21. But am still deviating in seeing a 20% chance for a rapid reassessment & steepening of the 10-yield above 2% should the Fed’s Jackson Hole meeting in August hint at a tapering of asset purchases. Plus a ramp up in vaccinations by the ROW. I'm with this school of thought https://www.cnbc.com/2021/06/18/inflation-breakout-will-soon-drive-10-year-yields-above-2percent-wells-fargo.html
Tapering market action following Fed statement
JPM can afford to wait out the current fall; https://on.mktw.net/3pWe3IG albeit Wednesday's FED report may give us more info @SE_Meyer / @Censusguyz  / @bobrown

I am officially sating i got the surge in inflation story wrong when i forecasted this question in February.  There is no surge coming. It is japan in the US. There is theory that the quantitative easing process taken to the extreme the Fed Reserve has taken it to actually becomed deflationary because of its impact on the repo markets. I am starting to wonder if it is true? It would explain Japan and what we see here in the US and some other countries.

It's below 1.5% right now.  So the crowd's 15% odds of it closing below that point seem incorrect. If the crowd is indeed right and the bond market is wrong, then this is a great chance to make some money, although I'm not sure how. Maybe buy put options on the 10-year Treasury?
The rate has decreased from 1.7 to 1.46 over the past month.

Regardless of what the outcome of the question is
Honestly never thought i would ever see inflation at 5% and the 10yr below 1.5% . Yesterday`s strong response to the fed auction indicates the market believes the inflation is transitory
https://www.cnbc.com/2021/06/10/inflation-hotter-than-expected-but-transitory-wont-affect-fed-policy.html Forecasting on questions wherein one has strong pre-existing biases are hard. I guess it helps to have a clean slate while forecasting

10 year auction today had the lowest yields just below 1.5% due to strong foreign demand. The inflation fears worldwide are making the United States the tallest midget in the room once again, but less so than in previous crisis I think.  This just goes to show how artificial the bond market is with the Federal Reserve buying up a regular amount on the back end. Who in their right mind would loan money to a country with consistent high deficits like the United States at 1.5%, when inflation is at 4.2%? It makes no sense but it means the answer to this question is more political than it is based on the fundamentals.
https://www.zerohedge.com/markets/surge-foreign-demand-sparks-stellar-10y-treasury-auction-ahead-tomorrows-cpi Tomorrow inflation will jump up again with the May CPI release. If the market starts to get squirrely I expect the Federal Reserve to increase Bond purchases.
Briefly dipped below 1.5% this morning. Crazy!
10 year yield is at 1.52%. Yields discounted to rise slightly and my personal view is that they are going up, but need to face facts
Mixed year leads to mixed result. 1.501 to 1.999 seems to be where the numbers will fall.

Transitory inflation and YCM will, in my opinion determine this one. There is, however, one potential fly in the ointment in the near term; a change to reverse repos to take some pressure off money market funds. Would that see a sell off in 3, 5 or 10 yr Treasuries? - https://reut.rs/3ppBuK8 @SE_Meyer what are your thoughts Sebbe?

This is my initial forecast. Using principles of technical analysis (see J Murphy, 'Technical Analysis'). Looking at the current weekly view, yield is flagging above 1.5. Failure of that level would mean a complete u-turn in my bias, but as it stands a move towards 2.0 looks more likely than anything. Period of time (gamma) remaining of course adds uncertainty.

10 year yield is currently 1.58% according to CNBC. Options are pricing a 4.2% price volatility (annualized), which assuming a rough 7 year duration translates to 60 bps of yield vol. It's .31 years to Sept 19, and so Sqrt(.31)*.6% = .33% standard deviation of yields. I'm assuming some upward drift in yields, about 15 bps, so my center point is .15% + 1.58% = 1.73%. Based on a mean of 1.73% and a vol of .33% and a rough assumption of normality (not a great assumption but fine for this), I get the probabilities here. I do have a feeling that yields are somewhat range bound, but that's a feeling not analysis. Link for volatility: https://www.barchart.com/futures/quotes/ZN*0/volatility-greeks
No changes - simple linear regression predicts 1.8, which is in line with existing growth.
Agree with @TJones97, @cafebedouin, and @alexandemeister here. Watching for their future analyses.
I made a thought-out forecast of this question last night  but I didn't save it. So here is my rough version that I spent no more than 3 minutes on.

Is the move into gold, precipitated by falling consumer confidence and home sales, going to be the spark that brings TMUBMUSD10Y down below 1.5%? (https://on.mktw.net/34i5PR8) "At the end of the day, gold is reacting to easing Treasury yields,” Michael Armbruster, managing partner at Altavest, told MarketWatch. “Thanks to surging inflation and wildly dovish Fed policy, real yields have been plunging.” on one hand. On the other hand, "“The question for gold traders is how long nominal Treasury yields will ignore spiking inflation data,” he said. “We think there is a good chance that nominal yields will play catch-up (rise) in the weeks ahead and that is a risk factor for gold in the short-run.”  Gold could be influenced in the short term by a) the ongoing pandemic in India (and falling wedding gold demand there) and b) Basel III in Europe in June (https://bit.ly/2T7bHKr) as well as falling yields and inflation expectations. @Juliabizz / @SE_Meyer what do you think?
@Juliabizz  & @SE_Meyer  Is this indicative of the 'transitory' inflation the FED is talking about? - https://bit.ly/2S1y6rY
This, https://on.mktw. net/3fi3wCp, suggests the FED is taking a 'steady as she goes' approach and is not likely to jump into action by this week's reports and events.
Whoops, forgot to actually update my forecast. +10 to 1.5-2.00, -10 from 2.0-2.500.
Made it as high as 1.7 but I don't see it getting much higher than that.

No reason for Powell to change his strategy; https://reut.rs/33C5cS9. US10yr (GT10:GOV) at 1.56% (https://reut.rs/2OWw0Io / https://bloom.bg/3usQ3hN) and hence a minor adjustment again. @Censusguyz I see you have had a bit of a change of heart in the last 5 days or so.
10 year at 1.47 after weak jobs report.

An adjustment based on https://reut.rs/3unbdOa & https://reut.rs/3nS1FrO & https://reut.rs/3tveAS5, Good jobs numbers but less than forecast. Jobs seems to be the driving issue for the FED and as Rosengren suggests, a temporary blip in inflation is likely simply because of the historic baseline and hence not likely to be a trend. All that should keep bond markets calmer for now and probably into September. That said, there's always the risk of an outlier or Black Swan.
Gundlach says that the Fed will get involved if rates exceed 225bp. I don't think rates will go below 1 unless we have a financial crisis (which wouldn't surprise me).
Adj from 50/50 to 66/34.  10 yr is 1.648 today.

Increasing likelihood of the higher buckets a bit. Trying to think more about what this will be like in September, we're due for higher monthly annual inflation numbers because spring and summer of 2020 had a dip in inflation. So the coming months will have higher inflation regardless of whether inflation is actually growing much, and if you combine that with inflation from reopening it could look pretty high temporarily. The lower baseline effects end a month or two before September, but I wonder if it will spook people unaware of the baseline effects resulting in higher treasury yields in September.
Current yield 1.62%. Assuming yield volatility of roughly 50 bps  and a moderate rise in yields just gives you a vastly different distribution than the crowd is forecasting

Now hovering around 1.6%, will the 10-yr yield stay under 2% through 3Q21 or spurt higher? The only largish economies posting significant recoveries ytd are China, US, UK.  As vaccination rates pick up over summer & restrictions ease in the rest of the world, economic growth, inflationary pressures & global competition for funds could kick in sooner rather than later. Hence 50:50 distribution.
4/14 = 1.64% with 5 more months to go at maybe 0.10% addition each month?

Possible to flirt w/ 2.4% between 12/2021 and 6/2022. 
In a defensive crouch among the crowd. This calls for an ugly excel spreadsheet... *wrings hands enthusiastically*

The yield curve is shifting slightly higher at the very long end.
Delays in stimulus and infrastructure/jobs bills may dampen fears of a rapid incline of inflation, while plans to raise taxes for those who can afford it, should improve the U.S. taxation base and limit effects of total indebtedness.
Thus, the 10y yield currently stabilizes at a relatively low level.

https://www.cnbc.com/2021/03/19/morgan-stanley-rise-in-us-10-year-treasury-yield-is-reasonable.html#:~:text=The%2010%2Dyear%20Treasury%20yield,in%20more%20than%20a%20year. "The 10-year Treasury yield jumped above 1.7% on Thursday, its highest level in more than a year. It came even though the Federal Reserve reassured investors that it had no plans to hike interest rates anytime soon, nor ease its bond-buying program."

The 10-yr rate is currently 1.715%.  Higher US Treasuries will pull money from places, e.g., Europe, with weaker economies and lower interest rates.  So I'm reducing the odds of "More than 2.5000" percent to zero.  Plus, the Fed will not want rates to rise too far too fast, which could derail the recovery.
The 10 year rate already stands at 1.7% today.  It is going to increase over the coming months.  The Fed doesn't control this rate the market does.

Higher rates:
- inflation concerns as a result of fiscal stimulus, reopening, and supply issues
- continued decrease in foreign demand for UST (including for political reasons, and risk of currency devaluation
Lower rates:
- high yields will break things, and so yield curve control will be used (effectiveness unknown) if and when it becomes an issue
- institutional flows and passive flows into USTs as the yields look better
- general flows into USTs if the stock market starts to falter

I'm bringing my forecast down. While I still see inflation at above 2.5% in September, I believe the FED will do yield curve control or other asset purchases to hold the yields down below inflation. The ECB has just started yield curve control. The others will follow. The question is, where will they hold it? I think things start to break when the 10 year hits 1.8, so that's a likely target. We're really not predicting a market, because this hasn't been a real market for years.

The trend for interest is clearly higher. With herd immunity reached sometime late summer in the US , I see more bonds investors reducing positions as the Fed will become less dovish as growth and inflation picked up. Therefore I  see the highest probability in the 2.0-2.5% range.
Inflation will be 2.5%, but the FED will probably implement yield curve control by September.

3/18 - 1.712% - yikes at this rate we could hit 2.0% by Q2 - moving the band higher
3/05 - 1.577%

Hedging my forecast for now. Markets are jittery albeit the outlook in US is improving quickly. See

The Fed is willing to anchor the short end of the yield curve but not the long end. Therefore they seem to be neutral if the yield curve keeps steepening in the US which means higher yields of UST 10s, 20s and 30s.
